data.title: Cheap Chick in the City
data.text:
Editorâ€™s Note: Again, thank you to all who found me after my appearance on #TheRehearsal with Nathan Fielder. Unfortunately, the Cheap Chick in the City has been REALLY stressed/busy lately and will be traveling/helping to celebrate her momâ€™s milestone birthday this coming week, BUT she managed to post some NYC w/e events, Her momâ€™s bday festivities are happening ALL w/e, so she is not going to publish a new post with full NYC events on Monday, (The Cheap Chick isnâ€™t quite sure what she is going to do yet, may be repeat of last weekâ€™s postâ€¦) She could also urgently use ANY financial assistance, esp since she has to move yet again on September 1st, you can provide, supporting her/the ws or â€œbuying her a cup of coffee or orange juice, no pulp ğŸ˜‰â€ you can Venmo her via @Patricia-Couture-3.

Sorry no pics, but now on to this weekâ€™s NYC events!

Saturday August 10th, 2024

â€œBronx Hip Hop Dayâ€œ

9 a.m. to 8 p.m.

P.S./I.S. 224345 Brook Avenue, The Bronx

â€œCelebrating all the elements of Hip Hop with Demonstration, teaching, panels and performances.â€

Cost: Free! For more info and to get tkts, go here,

â€œIntroductory Trail Runningâ€

9 to 11 a.m.

Greenbelt Nature Center in Blood Root Valley, 700 Rockland Avenue at Brielle Avenue, Staten Island

â€œAn introductory 3 mile run with short 15 minute walks to warm up and cool down. Perfect for anyone looking to learn how to stay healthy and safe while running on trails in the Greenbelt.

Additional instructions for participants: Bring comfortable running shoes and attire and water to stay hydrated.â€

Cost; Free! Get tkts here.

â€œBook Swapâ€

10 a.m. to 12;30 p.m.

Epiphany Library, 228 East 23rd Street, Manhattan

â€œBring one or more books to swap with other book lovers. Price of admission is one book to swap. Please bring clean books, no ripped pages, and in good condition! Limit to one bag or box of books to trade at a time. All genres and ages accepted. This event will be in person and take place in the YA area.â€

Cost: Free! (one book)

â€œCommunity Science Seiningâ€

10 a.m. to 12 p.m.

Pier 4 Beach in Brooklyn Bridge Park, Brooklyn

â€œDiscover the amazing biodiversity of the East River as Brooklyn Bridge Park staff and marine biologists use a seine net to catch-and-release incredible organisms that live below that waterâ€™s surface. Be ready for exciting discoveries! All ages are welcome at this free event.â€

Cost; Free!

â€œDragon Fest Panda Day #2â€

10 a.m. to 6 p.m.

7 Washington Square North, Manhattan

â€œAn annual outdoor Chinese food & culture festival with experiential activities, tastings, and market fairs.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œCameras and Coffee: Community Meet-Upâ€

11 a.m. to 12 p.m.

International Center of Photography, 79 Essex Street, Manhattan

â€œConnect with ICPâ€™s community during our monthly Cameras and Coffee social meet-up for photographers, collectors, and camera enthusiasts! During the event, grab a La Colombe coffee and pastries, available in the ICP cafÃ©.â€

Cost: Free! To get tkts, go here.

â€œMAD Backyard Block Partyâ€

11 a.m. to 3 p.m.

Museum of Arts and Design, Jerome and Simona Chazen Building, 2 Columbus Circle, Manhattan

â€œJoin us for an unforgettable Block Party, where fun, creativity, and community come together! This event will be packed with exciting activities for all ages and is free with registration. The Block Party will take place in MADâ€™s â€œbackyardâ€ on 58th Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue.

Cost: â€œFree with registration.â€ For more info and to get tkts, go here.

â€œBankra Caribbean Culture Festivalâ€

12 to 8 p.m.

Great Lawn in Archie Spigner Park, Queens

â€œThe Bankra Caribbean Culture Festival features traditional folk forms and experiences from different Caribbean territories.

Inherited from the Twi language of Ghana (boankra), a bankra is a large, woven basket made of indigenous materials in the islands of the Caribbean and is often carried or used as a display for a wide variety of produce, usually colorful and tantalizing to the eyes.

This is exactly what this festival replicates: the largesse and beauty of the folk culture represented from each island.â€

Cost; Free!

â€œEast Harlem Giglio Feastâ€

12 to 11 p.m.

114th-116th St. along Pleasent Ave., Manhattan

Celebrate the 115th anniversary of the feast with plenty of Italian entertainment inc music, food, games, rides, and more.

Cost: Free!

â€œCityparkâ€™s PuppetMobile Presents Cinderella Sambaâ€

1 p.m.

West 135th Street Plaza in St. Nicholas Park, Manhattan

â€œJoin NYC Parks and the Cityparks PuppetMobile for Cinderella Samba! The lively production features an original musical soundtrack that brings samba center-stage; handcrafted Carnaval festival floats on parade; and one-of-a-kind marionettes donning their most vibrant celebration costumes.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œEquity Library Theater Summer Play Festivalâ€

1 p.m.

Harry Belafonte 115th Street Library, 203 West 115th Street, Manhattan

â€œCome by the library to see some exciting plays! Equity Library Theater will be presenting short comedies by upcoming new writers from around the globe. Seating is limited, so be sure to arrive on time.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œInstant Shakespeare: â€˜Henry VI'â€

1 p.m.

Yorkville Library, Meeting Room, 222 East 79th Street, Manhattan

â€œThe Instant Shakespeare Company presents free readings of ALL of Shakespeareâ€™s plays annually. Join us for their dramatic reading of Henry VI. All ages are welcome.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œThe Worldâ€™s Fair Adventure Questâ€

1 p.m.

Unisphere in Flushing Meadows Corona Park, Queens

â€œJoin the Rangers for this exciting orienteering and history scavenger hunt adventure using the remaining monuments from the 1939 and 1964 Worldâ€™s Fairs in Flushing Meadow Park as the answers to historic clues. Participants will form teams and navigate the park using the clues as their guide as to discover history and gain an new appreciation for Queensâ€™ flagship park.â€

Cost; Free!

â€œAnimal Advocacy & The Artsâ€

2 p.m.

Seward Park Library, 192 East Broadway, Manhattan

â€œâ€œAnimal Advocacy and the Artsâ€ is a captivating exploration into the symbiotic relationship between creativity and animal advocacy. The talk spans literature, visual art, and cinema, including works by writers Virginia Woolf and George Orwell, photographer Ravi Agarwal, and ethical discussion of films such as Bong Joon-hoâ€™s Okja and Pixarâ€™s Finding Nemo. The lecture will be followed by a screening of the recently showcased short film How Do You Milk an Almond? â€” a whimsical stick-puppet musical loosely based on real-life lawsuits, providing an entertaining and reflective portrayal of current events. This new short film has received early praise from prominent filmmakers in animal advocacy, including the director of Cowspiracy, Keegan Kuhn (executive produced by Leonardo DiCaprio) and the director of The Animal People, Denis Henry Hennelly (executive produced by Joaquin Phoenix).â€

Cost: Free!

â€œPotluck at Ashford Learning Gardenâ€

2 to 6 p.m.

Ashford Learning Garden, 341 Ashford Street, East New York, Brooklyn

â€œCome to Ashford Learning Garden and enjoy a potluck day! The garden group invites everyone to come in and have some fun. Explore and enjoy this newly renovated garden and find out what the garden group has scheduled for this year. There will be games, music, and food. Please remember to bring a dish that you would like share (please note ingredients in your dish) or game you would like to play.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œReel to Read Movies: The Lady Vanishes (1938)â€ *Cheap Chick Recommends*

2 p.m.

Stavros Niarchos Foundation Library (SNFL), 455 Fifth Avenue, Manhattan

â€œThe Lady Vanishes (1938)

While travelling in continental Europe, a rich young playgirl realizes that an elderly lady seems to have disappeared from the train. Directed by Alfred Hitchcock.

1938 | PG | 97 minutes,â€™

Cost: Free!

â€œHindu Lamp Ceremonyâ€ *Cheap Chick Recommends*

3 to 7:30 p.m.

Pebble Beach in Brooklyn Bridge Park, Brooklyn

â€œJoin Brooklyn Bridge Park Conservancy at their 12th annual Hindu Lamp Ceremony at Brooklyn Bridge Park. Dance artist and educator Aeilushi Mistry brings peace and harmony to the community as she performs the traditional Hindu Aarti ceremony at Brooklyn Bridge Parkâ€™s Pebble Beach.

This event is a free walk-up event open to all; no advance registration required. This event is subject to change to weather or other extenuating circumstances.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œWorld Steelpan Appreciation Dayâ€

3 to 8 p.m.

Harbor View Lawn â€“ Brooklyn Bridge Park, Pier 1 â€“ Brooklyn Bridge Park, Brooklyn

â€œJoin to celebrate and experience the sounds and tastes of Caribbean culture!â€

Cost: Free!

â€œPaul Gagner â€“ â€˜The Cut of My Jibâ€™ Openingâ€

6 to 8 p.m.

Hashimoto Contemporary, 54 Ludlow St, Manhattan

â€œHashimoto Contemporary is pleased to present The Cut of My Jib, a new body of work by Brooklyn-based artist Paul Gagner.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œCharlotte AdigÃ©ry & Bolis Pupul | Sinkane | Ushkaâ€

7:30 p.m. (â€œDoors 6:30pm/Show 7:30pmâ€)

Prospect Park Bandshell in Prospect Park, Brooklyn

â€œCharlotte AdigÃ©ry & Bolis Pupul will transport you into a world of thought-provoking beats and exhilarating melodies. Defying conventions, the electrifying duo navigates issues like cultural appropriation and post-colonialism with infectious synth concoctions and an impressive ease. Known for their smash hit debut album Topical Dancer, which topped many criticsâ€™ â€œBest ofâ€ lists in 2022, their dynamic live shows are considered a do-not-miss. Sinkane will open, bringing his signature genre-bending style that infuses pop, funk, and electronic elements with the soulful rhythms of Sudan. DJ and multidisciplinary artist USHKA will kick off the nightspinning a wide range of diasporic club music.â€

Cost: Free! â€œ**RSVP to let us know youâ€™re coming and be entered for a chance to win two VIP tent passes! Sponsored by Bud Light**â€ Get tkts here.

Take a â€œPark Avenue Sculpture Strollâ€ today during Summer Streets, 7 a.m. to 3 p.m. Stop by â€œThe Grand Lawn, the rest stop will have lawn games, food, and refreshing drinks from GCT retailers.â€

â€œCatch live music at Pershing Square Plaza this Saturday from 12 p.m. to 3 p.m, featuring Judd Nielsen and the Neighborhood Crew.â€ (GCT)

There are some free screenings (+ a performance) today @ The Museum of the City of New York re the â€œChanging the Face of Democracy: Shirley Chisholm at 100â€ @ 1:15 p.m. and 4 p.m.

The â€œBlues BBQ Festivalâ€ is today from 1 to 9 p.m. @ Pier 76 in Hudson River Park!

Sunday August 11th, 2024

â€œVernam Barbadoes Preserve Coastal Cleanup & Seine Nettingâ€

9 a.m. to 12 p.m.

Rockaway Freeway Dog Park in Rockaway Freeway, 83-02 Beach Channel Drive, Queens

â€œVolunteer with the Stewardship Team to protect coastal areas in Vernam Barbadoes Preserve! Volunteers will help us remove the debris from the coastline creating a healthier ecosystem. We will also use a seine net to catch, observe and release some of the marine life of Jamaica Bay. Due to the strenuous nature of this event, it is not recommended for volunteers under the age of 14. Volunteers must be comfortable walking on uneven terrain. Face masks may be worn at your discretion. Come dressed in sturdy boots or shoes, long sleeves, long pants, and clothing that can get dirty. Space is limited and registration is required. Volunteers under 18 must be accompanied by a chaperone. To sign up a group of 10 or more volunteers please reach out to stewardship@parks.nyc.gov.â€

Cost: Free! Get tkts here.

â€œSpotted Lanternfly Trap Building with NYC H20â€

10 a.m. to 12 p.m.

Greenbelt Nature Center in Blood Root Valley, 700 Rockland Avenue at Brielle Avenue, Staten Island

â€œJoin NYC H2O at the Greenbelt Nature Center to build traps to stop the spread of invasive spotted lanternflies.Cost: Free! Get tkts here.

â€œWaterfront Walksâ€ (This event repeats every 2 weeks on Sunday between 6/2/2024 and 10/20/2024.)

10;30 a.m.

Pier 1 in Brooklyn Bridge Park, Brooklyn

â€œJoin Brooklyn Bridge Park Conservancy for a free walking tour of Brooklyn Bridge Park! Learn about the history of the Brooklyn waterfront, the Parkâ€™s sustainable design, and how the Park came to life. Waterfront Walks are held every other Sunday through October at 10:30 AM, starting from Pier 1.

Not an early bird? Come to a Sunset Waterfront Walk, which are offered twice monthly on Tuesdays and Sundays from May to October starting at Pier 1 at 6:30 PM.

All walking tours are free and weather dependent. RSVPâ€™s are required, as guests will be notified if there are cancellations or delays due to weather. Wear comfortable shoes, as these tours last approximately one hour. All tours meet outside Van Leeuwen at Fulton Ferry Landing.

All walking tours are free and weather dependent. RSVPâ€™s are required, as guests will be notified if there are cancellations or delays due to weather. Wear comfortable shoes, as these tours last approximately one hour. All tours meet outside Van Leeuwen at Fulton Ferry Landing.â€

Cost: Free! Get tkts here.

â€œNatureâ€™s Workshop: Natural Dyesâ€

11 a.m. to 12 p.m.

Lawn Area in Herbert Von King Park, Greene Avenue and Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn

â€œJoin the Urban Park Rangers in using natural materials to tie-dye in vibrant colors. Bring your own white cotton clothes or receive a free handkerchief or tote bag to dyeâ€

Cost: Free!

â€œBirding: Raptorsâ€

11 a.m.

Freshkills North Park Entrance in Freshkills Park, 350 Wild Avenue, Staten Island

â€œOur Urban Park Rangers will guide you to the best viewing spots in New York City to see birds of prey. Birding programs are appropriate for all skill levels and beginners are welcome. Join the Urban Park Rangers as we explore Freshkillsâ€™ marshy ecosystem and determine what kind of raptors make it their home.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œPride Hike: Nature Is For Allâ€

11 a.m. to 1 p.m.

The Overlook in Forest Park, Queens

â€œLearn more about queer way that nature has evolved in parks. Rangers will provide a fun and inclusive space for the LGBTQ+ community while hiking on the Orange Trail in Forest Park. During the hike, Rangers will talk about plants and animals that live in the park and why it is important to create safe spaces for everyone in the great outdoors.â€

Cost; Free!

â€œEast River Ecologyâ€

1 to 3:30 p.m.

Play Area in Twenty-Four Sycamores Park, Manhattan

â€œExplore the East Midtown Greenway. Rangers share the local ecology and natural history of the East River and highlight the resilient design of the new park and greenway.â€

Cost; Free!

â€œThe Four Corners of Crotonaâ€

1 to 2:30 p.m.

Crotona Nature Center in Crotona Park, Crotona Park East and Charlotte Street, Bronx

â€œJoin the Rangers on a long walk through the largest park in the South Bronx! Explore all four quadrants of Crotona Park, known for its serene views, unique wildlife, and important history.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œNatureâ€™s Workshop: Printmaking in the Parkâ€

1 to 2:30 p.m.

Blue Heron Nature Center in Blue Heron Park, 222 Poillon Avenue, Staten Island

â€œJoin the Urban Park Rangers as they teach you some fun and easy printmaking techniques. Printmaking is one of the oldest art forms and the original way of creating multiples of the same image. Rangers will show you how to replicate these techniques without using harmful chemicals or large machinery, yet still creating some beautiful artwork.â€

Cost; Free! Get tkts here.

â€œDays Afield on Staten Islandâ€

2 to 3 p.m.

Greenbelt Nature Center in Blood Root Valley, 700 Rockland Avenue at Brielle Avenue, Staten Island

â€œStaten Island OutLOUD celebrates the summer season and explores the writing of Island naturalist William T. Davis (1862-1945).â€

Cost: Free!

â€œGreat Jazz on the Great Hillâ€

3:30 p.m.

Great Hill, Central Park, Manhattan

â€œJazzmobile and the Central Park Conservancy present Great Jazz on the Great Hill! Enjoy an amazing lineup of world-renowned jazz performers while lounging or swing dancing in the Park. Bring a picnic blanket, snacks, and your dancing shoes for this fun, free event!

All ages are welcome.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œAfribembÃ© Festivalâ€œ

4:30 to 6:30 p.m.

Grantâ€™s Tomb, Morningside Heights, Manhattan

â€œThis year, we are thrilled to join forces with Harlem Week to bring our Pan-African festival to this historic celebration of the rich culture of our community, providing Harlem with an even more powerful experience.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œChinatown Block Partyâ€

4:30 to 8:30 p.m.

Mott & Mosco Streets, Manhattan

â€œFor our season finale, weâ€™re bringing dancer-DJs Gia Fu x YiuYiu ç‘¶ç‘¶ back together for a Chinese x Afro-Latin music crossover to close us out for the summer! Remember to bring along any special garments and textile remnants for this seasonâ€™s interactive art installation, With Flying Colors by Annika Cheng. These recycled textiles will be incorporated into a series of banner flags that will be flown over Corky Lee Way during future block parties. With Flying Colors seeks to honor Chinatown garment workers and the people who love and wear the clothing that speaks to the world about who we are.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œHIP TO HIP THEATRE COMPANY: â€˜THE WINTERâ€™S TALE'â€

5 p.m.

Socrates Sculpture Park, Queens

â€œKing Leontes falsely accuses his pregnant wife of infidelity with his best friend. Consumed by jealousy, he makes a series of catastrophic decisions that tear his family apart and leaves his newborn daughter abandoned. Sixteen years later, can time bring healing and reconciliation?â€

Cost: Free!

â€œWBLS 50th Anniversary: Jon B and Funk Flexâ€

5 p.m. (Doors)

Coney Island Ampitheater, 3052 West 21 Street, BK

â€œWBLS has been holding it down as the center of soul and R&B in New York City for decades. For this throwback jam in Coney Island, it assembles a collection of R&B stars from the late â€˜80s and â€˜90s sure to trigger nostalgic notions of love and tenderness, hosted by the legendary radio DJ Funk Flex.â€

Cost: Free! For more info, go here.

The â€œNational Dominican Day Paradeâ€ is today @ Noon and runs on Sixth Avenue

from 37th St to 55th St, in Midtown, Manhattan.

Thereâ€™s a special â€œOlympics Closing Ceremonyâ€ @ Rock Center today @ 2 p.m.

Today is the last day to enjoy free drop-in improv classes @ The Second City New York! (Also avail on Sat)

The â€œ43rd Annual Battery Dance Festivalâ€ â€“ In-Person and Via Livestreamâ€ kicks off today and runs thru Saturday August 17th, 2024!

**********************************************************************************************************

â€œPBS Great Performances: Merry Wives

Streaming until Monday, September 30 for FREE.

Free summer theatre season is coming to an end, which makes it the perfect time to revisit Merry Wives, Jocelyn Biohâ€™s fabulous one-act adaptation of the Bardâ€™s The Merry Wives of Windsor, recorded live at The Public Theaterâ€™s Shakespeare in the Park in 2021. Set in modern-day Harlem with ladiesâ€™ man Falstaff (Broadway vet Jacob Ming-Trent) attempting to woo two married West African immigrants, the show is an exuberant romp that celebrates broad comedy and Black joy. Saheem Ali directs an all-Black cast in this laugh-out-loud comedyâ€¦â€ (TDF)

###

All events were available @ time of posting. The Cheap Chick in the City is not responsible if events become sold out.

The Cheap Chick in the City will continue to tweet via @cheapchicknyc, so be sure to check there for SOME cheap and non-free things to do in New York City. Apologies for lack of Tweets recently, The Cheap Chick is working on it!

The Cheap Chick in the City is also available for special personalized messages etc. tips, advice, and ideas/suggestions for cheap and free things to do via the Cameo app including trip/vacation/wedding planning, birthdays, anniversaries, graduations, and doing cheap and free things in your hometown!

P.S. And yes folks, I am VERY real ğŸ™‚

Editorâ€™s Note: Again, thank you to all who found me after my appearance on #TheRehearsal with Nathan Fielder. The Cheap Chick in the City could still REALLY use your help, esp right now as she is struggling to pay July/August rent/bills, and since she only recently started a new job and NOW has to move again by September 1, so if you want to buy her a cup of coffee or a cup of orange juice, no pulp ğŸ˜‰ or just support the website, you can Venmo her via

@Patricia-Couture-3, EVERY little bit helps, thank you!

Hereâ€™s a link to my recent post, which still has some great free NYC summer events! And hereâ€™s a link to a previous post, which also has lots of great summer events in NYC.

Saturday August 3rd, 2024

â€œBrooklyn Beach Sports Festivalâ€ (Rain Date: Sunday, August 4, 2024)

10 a.m. to 5 p.m.

Coney Island Beach, West 10th Street Boardwalk Entrance, Brooklyn

â€œKick off your flip flops and come play at the beach â€“ the Brooklyn Beach Sports Festival is back! NYC Parks is partnering with National Calisthenics Awards to host competitive and non-competitive activities.â€

Cost: Free! For more info, go here.

â€œGreenbelt Native Plant Center Gardeningâ€

10 a.m. to 1 p.m.

Greenbelt Native Plant Center, 3808 Victory Blvd, Staten Island

â€œJoin the Greenbelt Native Plant Center staff for a gardening day! Tasks may include transplanting plants into bigger pots, weeding, seeding, moving potted plants, and other outdoor nursery activities. Volunteers in attendance may also help with GNPCâ€™s new volunteer vegetable garden program. Please come prepared for inclement weather outdoors, sturdy footwear, and long-sleeved shirts that can get dirty. It is also recommended to wear a hat and bring sunscreen. Space is limited and registration is required. Volunteers under 18 must be accompanied by an adult. To sign up a group of 10 or more volunteers please reach out to stewardship@parks.nyc.gov.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œNatureâ€™s Workshop: Wild Plant Bouquet Makingâ€

10 to 11:30 a.m.

Mother Carter Garden in Baisley Pond Park, Queens

â€œDiscover the art of crafting beautiful bouquets using wild grasses and plants. Join our knowledgeable Rangers on an identification walk and learn how to create stunning natural bouquets that will remain vibrant both fresh and dried.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œField Guide: Deep Looking: Points Of Connection Aboundâ€

11 a.m. to 1 p.m.

Socrates Sculpture Park, Queens

â€œFacilitated by Christina Delfico of iDig2Learn

Looking up at tree limbs or down to vast root systems below ground, weâ€™ll explore natureâ€™s exchange to unlock the hidden relatedness in our midst.

Lightning strikes give the soil nitrogen, and earth-bound fungi hug tightly to tree root tips teasing out sugars and sending back nutrients a tree could never absorb without the aid of their mycelium friends.

Come explore the park and the complex connections aboveground and underground with artists of Socrates and iDig2Learnâ€™s founder. Together we will share the latest science and create a colorful visual web of ribbon art in the River Birch grove to better understand the interconnectedness all living things do to heal, trade and repair.

Website: https://www.idig2learn.org/

Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/idig2learn/?hl=enâ€œ

Cost: Free! Get tkts here.

â€œColor Theory In Natureâ€

11 a.m. to 12:30 p.m.

Pelham Bay Nature Center in Pelham Bay Park, Bruckner Boulevard and Wilkinson Avenue, Bronx

â€œJoin the Urban Park Rangers on a fun and educational nature walk to learn all about how plants and animals use color in their everyday lives!â€

Cost: Free!

â€œPerformance and Workshop with Mark Morris Dance Groupâ€œ

11 a.m. to 4 p.m.

Brooklyn Bridge Park, Pier 1 Harbor View Lawn, Manhattan

â€œPresented by Brooklyn Bridge Park Conservancy, Mark Morris Dance Group (MMDG) returns to Brooklyn Park Bridge, for a special, outdoor performance and an all-ages family-friendly workshop.â€

Check brooklynbridgepark.org for the repertoire and details of the workshop. This event is subject to change to weather or other extenuating circumstances.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œForging Maritime Metalsâ€

12 to 2 p.m.

Pier 16, South Street Seaport, Manhattan

â€œVisit the Seaport Museum for drop-in metalworking demonstrations that delve into the crucial role of blacksmiths during the Age of Sail, both on land and aboard ships at sea. These events will spark interest into the maritime blacksmithing trade and provide visitors with insight into the construction and maintenance of historic vessels, like the 1885 tall ship Wavertree.

Metalworker and long-time Seaport Museum volunteer Barry Greene will enlighten viewers about the tools and materials employed by smiths. Through live showcases, he will demonstrate the historical art of crafting rivets, spikes, and various tools.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œGrill in the Gardenâ€

12:30 to 7 p.m.

Lincoln Avenue, Lincoln Avenue The Bronx

â€œLets Go. Enjoy food, drinks, good music & great vibes. Plant Based BBQ food in a luscious Floral Garden Smack Dab in the Heart of The City.â€

Cost: Free! For more info and to get tkts, go here.

â€œHistoric Tea Partyâ€

1 to 2 p.m.

H.H. Biddle House in Conference House Park, 70 Satterlee Street, Staten Island

â€œJoin the Rangers and travel back in time in the historic Biddle House. Learn the historical significance that tea has played throughout history and culture. Try an assortment of natural teas and lemonades from plants seen in the park while wearing your best Victorian dress! All materials provided by the Rangers.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œNational Film Registry Series: Don Siegelâ€™s Dirty Harry (1971)â€

2 p.m.

Seward Park Library, 192 East Broadway, Manhattan

â€œA rooftop sniper named Scorpio has killed twice. Streetwise San Francisco police detective Harry Callahan will nail the perp one way or anotherâ€”no matter what â€˜the systemâ€™ prescribes. The filmâ€™s story is based on the Zodiac Killer murders of the early seventies. (102 minutes)

â€”Robert Cashill, Cineaste.â€

Cost: Free!

(Image Source: Wikipedia.org)

â€œCocktails on the Farmâ€

5 to 8 p.m.

Urban Farm in Randallâ€™s Island Park, Manhattan

â€œJoin us for an evening of farm-to-high table cocktails and mocktails at the Urban Farm. Purchase and sample beverages infused with farm fresh flavors, savor freshly harvested snacks, and mingle with new and old friends. Ages 21+!â€ *Cheap Chick in the City Cheap Trick* â€œOne drink will be free for the first 150 participants.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œRCTA Summer Concert Series: August 3rd, 2024, Paul DeCosterâ€ (This event repeats every week on Saturday between 6/22/2024 and 8/10/2024.)

7 p.m.

96th Street Tennis Courts in Riverside Park, Manhattan

â€œThese FREE Concert evenings are highlighted by picnics and good company as live entertainment enthusiasts gather on the north lawn of the tennis courts to enjoy a variety of musical acts. The Sunset Concert Series is a prime example of how the RCTA aims to provide community engagement experiences for all. All Shows start at 7pm.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œâ€˜MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHINGâ€˜ Screeningâ€œ

8 to 10:30 p.m.

Queens Night Market at the New York Hall of Science in Flushing Meadows Park, Queens

â€œFree Outdoor Screening of The Publicâ€™s Free Shakespeare in the Park production recorded live by THIRTEEN for Great Performances on PBS

â€˜MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHINGâ€™

By William Shakespeare

Directed by Kenny Leon

Choreography by Camille A. Brown

In partnership with the Mayorâ€™s Office of Media and Entertainment and NYC Parks experience The Publicâ€™s Free Shakespeare in the Park production of MUCH ADO ABOUT NOTHING. Captured live from The Delacorte Theater in Central Park in 2019 by THIRTEENâ€™S Great Performances on PBS, catch Tony Award winner Kenny Leon direct a bold new take on Shakespeareâ€™s cherished comedy of romantic retribution and miscommunication.â€

Cost: Free! For more info, go here.

â€œNYC Summer Streetsâ€ are in Manhattan today and include music, performances, giveaways and more!

Get $.50-cent hot dogs on the UWS today!

Celebrate â€œFirst Saturdayâ€ @ the Brooklyn Museum!

Saturday August 3rd and Sunday August 4th, 2024

â€œEffective Effects with Foley Artist Matt Rockerâ€

â€œDemonstrations will take place at 1:00 p.m., 3:00 p.m., and 5:00 p.m. each day.â€

Museum of the Moving Image, 36-01 35 Ave, Astoria, Queens

â€œJoin the audio engineer and Foley artist Matt Rocker for a hands-on demo of practical sound design using everyday objects. Attendees will create their own sound effects that lend believability to film, television, and video games.â€

Cost: Free!

â€œThe Hong Kong Dragon Boat Racesâ€ are in Flushing Meadows Corona Park this weekend!

Itâ€™s Bank of Americaâ€™s â€œMuseums on Us Weekendâ€ + select NYC museums are free with BOA cardage!

Sunday August 4th, 2024

â€œPlanting the Pollinator Gardenâ€

10 to 11:30 a.m.

Bowling Green Cottage in Parade Ground, Brooklyn
